metadata.title: Algorithmic Linearly Constrained Gaussian Processes
metadata.author: Markus Lange-Hegermann
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: We algorithmically construct multi-output Gaussian process priors which satisfy linear differential equations. Our approach attempts to parametrize all solutions of the equations using Gröbner bases. If successful, a push forward Gaussian process along the paramerization is the desired prior. We consider several examples from physics, geomathematics and control, among them the full inhomogeneous system of Maxwell’s equations. By bringing together stochastic learning and computer algebra in a novel way, we combine noisy observations with precise algebraic computations.

highlights: Gaussian process regression has become a prime regression technique [37]

Examples of such assumptions are smooth or rough behavior, trends, homogeneous or heterogeneous noise, local or global behavior, and periodicity. Such assumptions are usually incorporated in the covariance structure of the Gaussian process
Thereby, despite their random nature, all realizations and the mean function of the posterior strictly adhere to these physical laws2
A map into the solution set for physical laws could be found by a computation that does not necessarily terminate

For different or more general operator rings see Subsection 2.3. This ring models linear differential equations with constant coefficients, as it acts on the vector space F = C∞(Rd, R) of smooth functions, where ∂xi acts by partial derivative w.r.t. xi
The paper constructs multi-output Gaussian process priors, which adhere to linear operator equations

summary: Gaussian process regression has become a prime regression technique [37].
Given by certain linear differential equations, could be incorporated into the covariance structures of Gaussian process priors.
GP x → μ(x) + (y − μ(X))k(X, X)−1k(x, X)T , (x, x ) → k(x, x ) − k(x, X)k(X, X)−1k(x , X)T , is again a Gaussian process and its mean function is used as regression model.
This ring models linear differential equations with constant coefficients, as it acts on the vector space F = C∞(Rd, R) of smooth functions, where ∂xi acts by partial derivative w.r.t. xi.
The set of realizations4 of a Gaussian process with squared exponential covariance function is dense in F.
The class of Gaussian processes is closed under matrices B ∈ R × of linear differential operators with constant coefficients.
Let g = GP(μ, k) be a Gaussian process with realizations in a space F of vectors with functions in F as entries.
4The realizations are the Cameron-Martin space (a reproducing kernel Hilbert space) translated by the mean function [28, Thm. 7.4].This only holds for Gaussian processes [4, p.
This lemma implies another advantage of choosing a zero mean function: it is always a solution of the linear differential equations.
Our goal is to construct Gaussian processes with realizations dense in the solution set solF (A) of an operator matrix A ∈ R × .
Parametrizations yield the denseness of the realizations of a Gaussian process B∗g in solF (A).
The theory presented for differential equations with constant coefficients holds for other rings R of linear operators and function spaces F.
Constructing a parametrization B of solF (A) yields a Gaussian process dense in the solution set solF (A) of an operator matrix A ∈ R × .
SolF (A) can be found by solving the homogeneous system of linear equations Ab = 0 with the Gaussian algorithm and write a base for the solutions of b in the columns of a matrix B.
The approach in this paper is the opposite by restricting the Gaussian process prior to solutions of an operator matrix.
We verify this and use the parametrization to construct a Gaussian process, such that its realizations adhere to Maxwell’s equations.
The paper constructs multi-output Gaussian process priors, which adhere to linear operator equations.
Experimental results would be interesting which covariance function for the parametrizing functions is most suitable
headline: This paper addresses these two problems from a complementary angle
